scenarios.introduction: Cardiac arrest is a sudden loss of heart function, breathing, and consciousness.

detailed_steps.step_description: Call 911 or local emergency services.
Perform CPR.
Push hard and fast on the person's chest.
100 to 120 pushes a minute.
Deliver rescue breaths after every 30 compressions.
Allow the chest to rise completely between compressions.
Keep doing this until an AED is available or emergency workers arrive.

scenarios.introduction: Choking occurs when a foreign object becomes lodged in the throat or windpipe, blocking the flow of air.
symptoms & causes: skin, lips, and nails turning blue

detailed_steps.step_description: Ask the person if they are choking.
If they nod yes, perform the Heimlich maneuver.
Stand behind the person and wrap your arms around their waist.
Make a fist with one hand and place it just above the personâ€™s navel.
Grasp the fist with your other hand and perform quick, upward thrusts.
Continue until the object is expelled or the person becomes unconscious.
If the person becomes unconscious, begin CPR.

scenarios.introduction: An allergic reaction occurs when the immune system overreacts to a harmless substance known as an allergen.

detailed_steps.step_description: Remove the person from the allergen if possible.
Call 911 or local emergency services if the reaction is severe.
Assist the person in using an epinephrine auto-injector if available.
Have the person lie still on their back.
Loosen tight clothing and cover them with a blanket.
If there is vomiting or bleeding from the mouth, turn the person on their side to prevent choking.
Begin CPR if there are no signs of breathing or circulation until emergency help arrives.

scenarios.introduction: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.
symptoms & causes: paralysis or numbness of the face
trouble seeing in one or both eyes

detailed_steps.step_description: Call 911 or local emergency services immediately.
Check if the person is breathing and has a pulse.
If the person is unconscious but breathing, place them in the recovery position.
Do not give them any food or drink.
Monitor their condition until emergency services arrive.

scenarios.introduction: A seizure is a sudden, uncontrolled electrical disturbance in the brain. It can cause changes in your behavior, movements, feelings, and levels of consciousness.

detailed_steps.step_description: Stay with the person and start timing the seizure.
Keep the person safe by moving them away from harmful objects.
Turn the person onto their side to help them breathe.
Place something soft under their head.
Do not put anything in their mouth.
Call 911 if the seizure lasts more than 5 minutes or if another seizure starts soon after the first.

scenarios.introduction: Burns are tissue damage caused by heat, overexposure to the sun, or other radiation, chemical or electrical contact.

detailed_steps.step_description: Cool the burn with running cool (not cold) water for at least 10 minutes.
Remove any clothing or jewelry near the burn site.
Cover the burn with a sterile, non-adhesive bandage or clean cloth.
Do not apply creams, oils, or ice to the burn.
Seek medical attention if the burn is severe or covers a large area of the body.

scenarios.introduction: Poisoning occurs when a person is exposed to a substance that can cause illness or death.

detailed_steps.step_description: Call 911 or your local poison control center immediately.
Try to determine what poison was taken, when, and how much.
Do not induce vomiting unless directed by a medical professional.
If the person is unconscious but breathing, place them in the recovery position.
Monitor their condition until help arrives.

scenarios.introduction: Heat stroke is a condition caused by your body overheating, usually as a result of prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures.

detailed_steps.step_description: Call 911 or local emergency services immediately.
Move the person to a cooler environment.
Remove excess clothing.
Cool the person with whatever means available, such as cool water, fans, or ice packs.
Monitor their condition until help arrives.

scenarios.introduction: Hypothermia occurs when your body loses heat faster than it can produce heat, causing a dangerously low body temperature.

detailed_steps.step_description: Call 911 or local emergency services immediately.
Move the person to a warmer environment.
Remove any wet clothing and replace with dry blankets or clothing.
Warm the person gradually, starting with the body core (chest, neck, head, and groin).
Provide warm beverages if the person is conscious and able to swallow.
Monitor their condition until help arrives.

scenarios.introduction: An asthma attack is a sudden worsening of asthma symptoms caused by the tightening of muscles around the airways (bronchospasm).

detailed_steps.step_description: Help the person sit up and stay calm.
Assist them in using their quick-relief inhaler.
If symptoms do not improve within a few minutes, call 911 or local emergency services.
Monitor their condition until help arrives.
Encourage slow, deep breathing.
